title: When will the first Major League Baseball game of the 2020 season be played?
preds: It is July 15 and no MLB games yet
Won't be starting before this timeframe now.
Deal reached.  Season starts late July
Opening day is now planned for July 23rd or 24th [1]. Players report July 1st. [1] https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29354014/sources-mlbpa-agrees-report-july-1-discussing-health-safety-protocols
news today. planned date is july 23rd.

"MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred said players will report to spring training on July 1 and the regular season is to begin either on July 23 or 24." https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/06/23/882641122/baseball-is-coming-back-for-a-pandemic-shortened-2020-season

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-baseball-mlb/mlb-league-players-agree-to-60-game-season-starts-in-july-idUSKBN23V04H Says here a week after this deadline.  Might be later but it won't be sooner.
Initial forecast.  Joining forecast late.  Current MLB plan is for opening day around 24 July 2020.

"Major League Baseball had 40 players and staff members test positive for COVID-19 in the past week, creating a sense of urgency in labor negotiations between the owners and players, according to two persons with direct knowledge of the situation ... The players postponed their vote Sunday whether to accept or reject MLB’s plan for a 60-game season with full pro-rated play after commissioner Rob Manfred telephoned union chief Tony Clark and e-mailed tweaks to MLB’s last proposal ... MLB still is offering 60 games, guaranteeing the players about $1.5 billion, but the recent surge of positive tests now will further delay the start season. The resumption of spring training now will be no earlier than June 29, with the season starting July 26." https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/2020/06/21/mlb-2020-deal-season-schedule/3233083001/
Simply not enough time to end the stand-off and then give teams  proper access to training etc. Plus there is still the small matter of a global pandemic to deal with.

Negotiations between MBL and the players union are active and concern details such as pay and number of games. Proposal around june 12th were for a July 14th start. Proposal around June 17 was for a July 19th start.
The MLB restart plan seems to be held hostage by demands on the owners and players sides.  This makes a restart before 16th July highly unlikely. So revising my initial predictions.

Things look rough for MLB — they are still embroiled in a labor dispute and now there have been players who have tested positive for COVID-19 https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-surge-throws-another-curve-at-baseballs-restart-plans-11592600803
They don't even have an owner/player agreement yet and would have to set up all the logistics and testing.  Can't do it that fast.
Now looking like July 19th is the earliest possible date.

Note: I'd love to be wrong. I miss baseball.
I have no faith in the owners. https://media.tenor.com/images/14d6e67749fd3228549b7650f545f489/tenor.gif
No agreement in sight. Players would need 1-2 weeks to report for Spring Training, which would likely last ~3 weeks.

https://apnews.com/8db7e07193afb7c6868d6bc722deb64e
The Commish says they need to make sure there's a season "for the benefit of our fans."  A Nats pitcher expostulates that "the fans do not deserve this."   As one of the fans that they're both so deeply concerned about, I find it heartwarming that the possibility of great financial loss is not a consideration for either party.  I look forward to receiving the benefits I deserve--but probably not this month.  Coming down some more.

See previous forecast notes plus https://nypost.com/2020/06/15/rob-manfred-not-confident-mlb-2020-season-will-happen/  plus Trevor Bauer's tweets. If MLBPA agrees to not file a grievance, or negotiation moves to arbitration,  its hard to believe those will happen fast enough to  still fit in spring training before a July 15 1st game.

"MLB commissioner Rob Manfred 'not confident' there will be a 2020 season" https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/columnist/bob-nightengale/2020/06/15/mlb-2020-season-negotiations-stall-baseball-ponders-next-move/3190994001/

I'm reducing the probability that the first game will be before July 16. Monday's MLB conference call just ended saying they will have to negotiate the health and safety terms with the MLBPA while they set the schedule. So maybe it can still happen but Manfred just when on the record saying he is no longer confident there will be a season at all. Could all be negotiating tactics. Need a week for to move players to spring training then 3 weeks of training so if the agreement on non-salary terms is not there in a few days, the season would start after the 16th.

I asked for clarification (if only for my own peace of mind) as to make certain we are talking about the first official, regular season game. I know the question implies that, but the verbiage is too vague for my tastes.
After all, spring training has already occurred and one could argue the first MLB game of 2020 has already been played. We should be clear that we are forecasting regular season. With that out of the way... hoo boy!
Buckle up for a wild ride folks, this one has the potential to be a close one! "
When could a 50-game season start?
In its most recent and probably final proposal, MLB suggested a July 14 Opening Day for a 72-game regular season. Assuming players need at least two weeks to ramp back up after having spring training interrupted and allowing some additional time for health and safety protocols and other logistical issues to be finalized, that may be an ambitious time-table. So if Manfred does as expected and implements that shorter season, then look for a scheduled Opening Day to fall between the middle of July and Aug. 1. MLB will want to get things going as soon as possible in the hopes that a full postseason can be played before COVID-19 possibly surges in the fall, but a start of the season prior to that two-week window is probably no longer possible. 
" Mid July to August. As in the cusp of our buckets. Then there is the prospect of owners signing off and/or bowing out.  I love their enthusiasm.... but to ramp up, get infrastructure in place, secure and train personnel, wrangle talent, break the bad news to the hot dogs AND warm up on the field is a huge effort!
Will they do it fast? Yes! Will they do it in a month? ehhhh ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
They're trying to build the plane and fly it at the same time. I'm taking a defensive stance until WED and then going back to my brutally realistic cynicism. Read the article I refer to here:
https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/why-mlbs-2020-season-will-still-be-played-despite-labor-fight-and-when-the-schedule-could-start/
Even if the players agree to a deal, the owners proposed July 14 start date will slip.  Logistics and scheduling will be obstacles.

"...Once the season is scheduled -- either because Manfred does so unilaterally or the two sides come to an agreement --  teams will need about 10 days to prepare their training camp sites. An abbreviated three-week spring training would follow. MLB wants the regular season to end no later than Sept. 27 to ensure the postseason doesn't extend into November. Based on that, spring training would have to begin no later than early-to-mid July for a 50-ish game season." https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlbpa-rejects-latest-proposal-tells-mlb-to-schedule-2020-season-tell-us-when-and-where/

I'm clawing back my aggressive and uncharacteristic "all in" -- I'm cynical about owners and players coming to an agreement and am equally cynical about both sides' enthusiastic desire to get paid.  Also, I'm an idiot. Does this question mean *any* game??
Including ST 2.0 exhibition games? The question is ambiguous enough to suggest "yes."
All it says is "first Major League Baseball game of the 2020 season" but doesn't explicitly say regular season but that is how I interpret it. If so, I'm dumb. 
If they make an agreement on Wednesday, then the first Corona League game will be in two weeks (!!!) Also, I like the idea of calling Spring Training 2.0 "Corona League" (a la Cactus League etc.) That said, from the minute the ink dries, I expect no less than 30 days from that moment to that of the first regular season first pitch.
There's infrastructure to secure, families to pack up, hotels, shuttles, testing kits, Union media crew, auxiliary operations resources to secure, etc. So I have some painful decisions and clarifications needed.
I owe @Dillyweed for catalyzing some deeper contemplation on my part. Here are my considerations...
If GJO says "any game" then I'll concede 25% / 75% If MLB signs an agreement by WED 17 JUNE, I'll go 50% / 50% If both, I'll explode. More on my rationale here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1055642

Latest reports are that the best that can be done is a 50 game season [2], based on the rejection by the players' union of the latest league offer that they are not going to respond to [1,2].  Per my previous forecast, a 50 game season can start in late July, with negotiations on the last bit of stuff happening [2] until as late as July 1st [3]. Seeming like anything earlier than mid-July is very, very unlikely at this point. [1] https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2896085-mlbpa-rejects-mlbs-recent-72-game-season-offer-will-not-counter
[2] https://www.sny.tv/mets/news/latest-on-negotiations-for-2020-mlb-season-players-union-rejects-latest-offer-and-will-not-counter/313424154
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1049319
Given the current offer and climate around the pandemic, I can see a 72 game season starting on July 14th.

I'm not ready to go all in like @Jayce  It seems the sides are far apart, which could be reality or 11th hour negotiating tactics. I think it's more likely to be the latter because both sides have a strong interest in playing a season. Most of their revenue comes from TV and with so many people shut up at home I would imagine that would be even more true this year.  However, even if there is an agreement in the next few days (which is a big if), there is also reality of scheduling games and at this point it seems like the first games somewhere around the weekend of July 11 is the earliest possible timeframe assuming the following article has its facts right:  https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29303960/mlb-union-remain-divided-full-prorated-salaries  "Both parties had hoped to be in spring training 2.0 by Wednesday. The earliest teams could gather at this point would be June 22, and with a three-week period to prepare for a season, a mid-July start is the likeliest outcome for a longer season. Every day that burns off the calendar also lessens the potential length of a season, which is likely to prompt a final showdown in the coming days, according to sources."
Trevor Bauer explains the state of the negotiations: https://mobile.twitter.com/BauerOutage/status/1271552251379593217

"...baseball has been mired in additional labor talks and losing the PR battle as the sides publicly bicker over money...both recent proposals have a July 10th start date for the regular season...It's said there's about a week left to hammer out an agreement, or the owners could impose a very short season of about 50 games. Without needing the player's approval." https://www.npr.org/2020/06/11/874311586/bubbles-and-empty-seats-pro-sports-forge-ahead-with-comebacks-despite-the-pandem
Time to ramp up and disagreements between labor and owners.
not a peep about this in the news as of 6/11/2020

To fit in the currently proposed 76 game season, they would need to start by around the first week of July, 10th at the latest [1]. But to get a 50 game season in, negotiations could continue until the 1st of July [1], which would mean starting the season in late-July. As of today, the players union is proposing an 89 game season, staring July 10th which owners aren't that interested in [2]. Stadiums, though, will need to get ready, and there seems to be little chance of all the stars aligning for an early July start [3].  While there may be a chance for this to turn around, it seems pretty unlikely at this point. Moving most of my forecast into after July 16th. [1] https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29282383/are-closer-2020-mlb-season-answering-questions-new-76-game-proposal
[2] https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-2020-season-update-where-things-stand-as-players-union-makes-89-game-proposal-to-owners/
[3] https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/mlb/report-hope-is-dwindling-as-mlb-season-now-appears-delayed-until-august/ar-BB158io0

No clear path for MLB yet between players and owners.  
NBA announced start date 31 July.
NHL has announced path/approach but not sites or start date.

Negotiations between players union and owners not going well, and players have very little leverage. https://theathletic.com/1857108/2020/06/06/rosenthal-a-july-4-return-is-all-but-gone-with-baseball-as-far-from-a-deal-as-ever/

Very interesting detail in Washington Post article (Source: https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/06/05/mlb-union-return-plan-faq/) If players will need a month and there is at least another week of negotiations, hard to see July 16 happening. What’s the drop-dead deadline for getting the season off the ground? There really isn’t one, but it would take roughly a month to go from a deal to Opening Day because pitchers need a spring training of about three weeks to build up arm strength. This week had been considered a soft deadline for holding Opening Day around July 4, and that target could still be hit if a deal were struck next week. But if the season were to be, say, 50 games, it wouldn’t need to start until as late as the second week of August. The only thing certain regarding the calendar is that MLB does not want to push the playoffs into November, because the postseason is its biggest driver of revenue and it fears a second wave of the coronavirus in the fall forcing the cancellation or suspension of the postseason. So at the least, this process could stretch on for another week or two.

I was at 100% no way before July 16, but reducing that to 30% to see what happens over next week. Rob Manfred wants the season to start early-mid July.  Players aren't happy, but the 50 game season is a likely outcome. 3 weeks min needed for a "Spring Training ", so something needs to happen fast to make July 15. Could cut it very close. https://www.houstonchronicle.com/texas-sports-nation/astros/article/Astros-would-host-spring-training-at-Minute-15318307.php

Might as well go all in; if the season happens at all...
I think players deserve their prorated salary rather than an arbitrary cut. Without the players, there is no game and we're talking a talent pool that isn't readily replaceable. Clearly, to play would put their health at risk and require major interruption to their regular lives that others aren't subjected to. THEN AGAIN, everyone who has been furloughed or laid-off would gladly be spend two months in Arizona playing baseball for 23% of $36 million. When we talk about labor disputes in professional sports, I like to take a step back and appreciate the big picture: this is the intersection of corporate greed and grown men who get paid to play a game.
As I grow older, I can't shake how absurd existence is sometimes. https://apnews.com/4d50060f444a6e5b18d8f9be5612b220

"A shortened schedule would run in contrast with what the players sought in a proposal sent to the league Sunday. The league's first proposal to the union offered an 82-game schedule with significant salary cuts. Multiple players told ESPN they would not abide a shorter schedule, with one saying, "We want to play more games and they want to play less. We want more baseball."" https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29252811/sources-mlb-mulls-shorter-season-full-prorated-salaries-players No agreement for 114-, 82- and now they would find an agreement for 50 games? 
If they do at all, small chance this will be for a <16july start, imo.

Possible 50 game season beginning in July https://mobile.twitter.com/JeffPassan/status/1267565933729583109 But when in July? Obviously late July allows  time to play 50 games, although  spreading the season out might make more financial sense(?). MLB thinks owners may be able to force this 50 game season with pro rata pay since it complies with March agreement by players for pro rata pay.

Gonna give some to the lower range, but still not convinced this will work out in this timeframe to give it more than this right now. Too many people involved, still too much uncertainty and unknows. Also not convinced the proposal = close to being +ev in the long rung for both. https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29248967/mlb-having-tougher-returning-nba-nhl-baseball-problem

MLB requires more players and staff than the NBA and I've heard of no concrete progress.
If plans were announced it'd likely still be another month just to ramp up, let alone find some sort of safe solution while agreeing on compensation. If progress were made, we'd hear it, as it would be big news - there is no value in making it a surprise; this isn't a birthday party. 
I think this forecast is VERY conservative... "16 June" bucket is halfway between a bad bet and impossible.
Owners and players not even close.
Not hearing any progress in negotiations.

A deal looks close on this, with a number of governors okay with no-fans playing [1]. "Governors from New York, California and Texas announced Monday that pro sports could return in their states by early June" [2], with Mayor Walsh in Boston having similar words about the Red Sox being back, noting he heard they were trying to be back by the 4th of July [3].  No date update is available from the MLB in what I could find. With that in mind, I am going to stick with my current forecast, and keep an eye open for any dates to be released. [1] https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-mlbpa-talks-progressing-toward-deal-for-2020-season-says-very-confident-player-representative/

[3] https://www.boston.com/news/coronavirus/2020/05/19/watch-boston-mayor-marty-walsh-holds-first-press-conference-since-release-of-states-reopening-plan

https://www.baseballamerica.com/stories/proposing-a-44-game-2020-mlb-season-expanded-playoffs/
Games with No Crowds in stands.
So weird... May 17th and not a single baseball game.

I think that the chances of games in first half of July have increased  a bit recently because MLB is proceeding with plans for that.  The major issue seems to be whether player compensation can be agreed.  Most likely outcome is still a delay till after July 16 or a complete cancellation.

The only hitch in an early July start seems to be the revenue sharing plan. I think that there's a better than even chance that the two sides come to some agreement in time to play. Both sides are motivated to get the deal done, and they have a decent amount of time to agree on something and still start before July 16. Still, any spike in cases from now until July could make a season very unlikely.
https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-2020-season-plan-owners-approve-proposal-for-july-start-talks-reportedly-begin-without-salary-discussion/

"Major League Baseball owners will submit a proposal to the players' union to start its 2020 season in July without fans...If the proposal is approved by the baseball players' union, Opening Day would take place around July 4 weekend and spring training would start in early to mid-June." https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/11/854146717/mlb-owners-propose-opening-day-in-early-july

"Major League Baseball has formalized its plan to return to the field, with teams agreeing Monday on a proposal to send to the players’ union for an 82-game season that would start without fans in early July ... The plan must clear major obstacles to become reality. Even if the union accepts the structure of a truncated season, the sides would also have to agree on a salary structure for players. The league would also need to have enough tests for players and employees without depleting the public supply, and agree with the union on working conditions, including protocols in case of positive tests." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/11/sports/baseball/coronavirus-baseball-mlb-restart.html

https://theweek.com/speedreads/913859/mlb-owners-sign-plan-start-season-july-4th-weekend I gather that the intrusion of designated hitters into the National League is a one-off to be discontinued after the truncated season, and I sure hope this is the case.  I happen to know that all the officially recognized deities wanted major league baseball never to live west of St. Louis; that they all still regard the Mets as an expansion team; and that they are all angry at whoever misplaced the stone tablets limiting baseball teams to nine players at a time.  Retribution surely looms.  Frankly I expected it with the rule change that you don't have to throw four pitches for an intentional walk.  I suppose the major deities are more lenient than I am.

I'm making this forecast based on some of the reading that I've been doing from ESPN, where it sounds like a June 10th start date for spring training might still be possible. Given that information, spring training is usually 3-4 weeks long, so therefore the first game would happen in early July. However, depending on if players themselves would feel safe to play again, I think that there is also the possibility that there won't be any games played before July 16.

Cleveland telling players to prepare for a July 1 opening day https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/one-mlb-team-reportedly-told-players-july-1-could-be-a-possible-target-date-for-opening-day/ Still think that will be too early but the first half of July cannot be ruled out.
July is being talked about as a best case scenario - https://nypost.com/2020/05/06/mlb-ramping-up-plans-for-best-case-july-start-to-2020-season/

"After a five-week delay due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Korea Baseball Organization (KBO) is finally ready for opening day...The KBO's success or failure could be an indication of how MLB may look to proceed when it's ready to begin play, possibly by late June." https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/05/05/850712890/despite-delays-caused-by-coronavirus-regular-season-baseball-starts-in-korea

Based on reports that MLB wants 5 weeks of preseason and to open in early July.  At this point, I think something will have to give.  Many states have not peaked and I expect MLB to be fairly cautious about this.  Also with how things are shaking out, it looks like NBA may cancel season, so that would make baseball first mover of professional sports, also arguing caution.

Looks like season will start either Late-June or Early-July. https://nypost.com/2020/04/28/mlb-2020-season-possibility-july-mets-yankees-division/ https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/columnist/bob-nightengale/2020/04/28/mlb-optimistic-about-starting-season-late-june/3039275001/

https://apnews.com/9bf7ae8115cf52f2f35f5915f45a86f0
MLB has engaged the Infinite Improbability Drive.  Stay tuned.

The MLB is currently saying before the 4th of July [1] / late June [2]. [1] https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-could-start-2020-season-with-opening-day-by-fourth-of-july-report-says/
[2] https://www.si.com/mlb/2020/04/28/mlb-start-season-late-june-realigned-divisions
Recent news article about potentially starting up the season sooner. https://www.cbc.ca/sports/baseball/mlb/mlb-return-june-july-report-1.5548104
MLB Discussing starting in late June (https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/columnist/bob-nightengale/2020/04/28/mlb-optimistic-about-starting-season-late-june/3039275001/)
4/27 They might play with no fans.

Given President Trump would like to reopen the economy asap, sport is one of the indicator to suggest the US economy is back to "business as usual". However, having the crowd to gather together in the ballpark is the situation that goes against containing the pandemic. Also, even Spring training will not resume, the league needs to have a few warm-up games/tournaments before the season officially resumes. Therefore, it is more likely it will start in June or July unless they really push it to open in the next month.

There will a lot of pressure from White House to see sports played by mid summer so even though they will not be played on traditional stadiums, I can see a "Cactus League" or "Palm League" approach in Arizona or Florida without spectators (same approach for NFL ) for TV revenues.

"...source said a more prudent outlook would be to wait another two months and see what the global landscape looks like then. If a baseball season starts in mid-July, it could be treated like past strike-shortened seasons, where teams would play a reduced schedule, and playoffs could extend into November." https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/plans-start-mlb-season-amid-coronavirus-pandemic-are-just-bit-n1181986

Intervention effects are slower and testing capacity remains too low.  Even as economy opens, large gatherings will be restricted. When restrictions begin to lift, players will need practice time before starting again.
Adjusting as there seems to be interest in playing a game in an empty stadium which increases the likelihood of it being sooner.
We have to go down the other side of the curve.

New report yesterday suggested that MLB could start as early as mid-May, but I think that is overly aggressive. I think how Korean baseball league fairs with their return will have a significant impact on how MLB approaches theirs. Not to mention, will need several weeks to ramp guys back up and they likely will not even be able to get together until mid-May. I see beginning to mid June being the earliest, with beginning of July being most likely.

There is a push to start baseball in Arizona as early as May (https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/news/mlb-opening-day-2020-baseball-when-date-countdown/5zmj59xogfhf1lqvud4v8h38r), which seems very optimistic considering at a March 25 press conference, state Health Director Dr. Cara Christ said that if infections continue at their current pace, illnesses would peak in April and hospitalizations would peak in May (https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/arizona-health/2020/04/06/coronavirus-covid-19-arizona-update-monday-april-6-cases-2-456-65-known-deaths/2952287001/).  Also, the players need time to practice and get in "game" shape. MLB has been discussing starting the season July 1 to end October 15 (https://mlb.nbcsports.com/2020/04/01/rumor-mlb-execs-discussing-100-game-season-that-would-begin-july-1/), which seems more realistic considering the current state of COVID-19.  Anything beyond that date would likely result in cancelling the season.
MLB already talking about playing games in empty stadiums as early as may. https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/29004498/mlb-union-focused-plan-allow-season-start-early-arizona

I'm updating my forecast because the MLB just announced a plan to play games during the coronavirus pandemic. The plan seems a little bit out there though, and has not been agreed upon. The plan looks like it would take effect as early as May, but they said June is more realistic. This looks like a desperation move, and desperation moves often fail. I'm more optimistic, but not that optimistic.

Reported on 4/7: "Major League Baseball and its players are increasingly focused on a plan that could allow them to start the season as early as May and has the support of high-ranking federal public health officials who believe the league can safely operate amid the coronavirus pandemic, sources told ESPN."
They could play games for TV with no fans. Rapid tests for all players and people involved.
Updated for rumors that MLB is in talks for season starting 7/1.  Still think cancellation is most likely.
Wimbledon was just cancelled, so I'm upping my possibility that the season will be cancelled as well (or at the very least postponed to that last possible moment to still have a season).
"anything before a mid-June starting point seems highly unlikely." https://nypost.com/2020/03/30/florida-coronavirus-order-could-further-delay-mlb-2020-season/
They're gonna shoot for the 4th of July.
Hysteria and "over abundance of caution" shall prevail
from a health prospective we should not have mass gatherings but more likely to be played with no audience.  financial pressure may get it going earlier than it should.

Rolling my forecast back - heavier in the 16 May to 15 June window. Basing newfound optimism on indications in the stock market. Three days of record gains, even despite the escalating COVID-19 diagnoses and deaths, indicate to me the country is realizing that we're going to have to get the economy moving again WHILE we deal with this virus, not after. And, I think creative Americans (God love em) are finding clever ways to resume operations. Airlines are offering $8k if you contract COVID-19 while flying with them (a rather nice incentive); groceries are delivering like crazy; businesses are figuring out how to get employees tested to rebuild customer confidence. Likewise, my guess is that sports will be able to resume when they apply basic social distancing principles to attendance (maybe sell every other seat, etc). The show must go on.

The situation is becoming a very dangerous cocktail;
Unemployment-employment-states with different measures, money pump without a reason,...total  trainwreck in the making.
Due to the COVID-19 virus' spread the MLB will not have a game before July 16, 2020.

The closest comparison class I can find is the outbreak of Pneumonic plague in Britain in 1349. The outbreak in the 14th Century England lasted roughly nine months... from November, 1348 until June, 1349. Pneumonic plague was a follow-on of Bubonic plague; aka ‘The Black Death’ which reached Britain in late 1348.  Victims who succumbed to the pneumonic form displayed none of the boils associated with the Bubonic Plague.
Relatively recent research has shown that the virulent fast-moving pneumonic form was a respiratory disease... one that initially preyed upon the weak and malnourished, then spread, rapidly, via person to person in close quarters, via discharge expelled from the lung. In 1349, little was known of respiratory disease, close quarters and transmission. The epidemic peaked in the cool months Feb- April 1349 and abated almost as rapidly and virtually disappeared by Pentecost - which in 1349 was 31 May. This may be explained by several factors; warming temperatures, higher levels of Vitamin D, (sunlight) and increased nutrition. Increased availability of meats, fish, fresh fruits and vegetables.  It is thus reasonable to suspect the coronavirus could crest and then abate in Europe on a similar curve, and in the US 15-20 days behind.

The virus is allegedly not thermophilic. Therefore, an outdoor event would benefit from the heat to kill the virus. In history, many pandemics have waves. Ceteris paribus, one might anticipate that as the weather changes in the fall, there is a higher likelihood of disease resurgence.   In the "dog days" of summer, there should be a lull in the number of cases. This would convince companies to start operating again. Also as the weather gets colder that false sense of security will likely be the catalyst for the next wave of the disease outbreak.
Some additional "Pre-Season" games may be required.  Coronavirus needs to ramp down significantly.  American public wants baseball season to begin for restoration of normalcy.

MLB like all sports leagues will resume play as early as feasible for financial reasons.  However I foresee a long time suspense for controlling COVID sufficiently for large gatherings to resume. The All Star Game was to be played 7/14/2020.  If the virus is suppressed by warmer weather as theorized, full summer in Northern Hemisphere is a good target date.  Baseball players, owners and fans are a culture of traditionalists, so anchoring to the putative All Star Game date as the new opening day for a half season of play is in my view a “boosted” outcome.

While Covid-19 will go on for a few months, I think people's patience for cancelling events will soon run out. People will become accustomed to the threat level and slowly normal service will creep back in, even though the threat will get worse til May/June.

Just a guess, and as always, I could be wrong.
